ygData.subject: Install W/MATLAB Problem
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi-- I just installed CANTERA 1.5 (Win XP Pro), and as you might expect from Murphy s Law, I tried to follow the instructions and messed up. After the CANTERA

Hi--

I just installed CANTERA 1.5 (Win XP Pro), and as you might expect fr=
om Murphy's Law, I tried to follow the instructions and messed up.

After t=
he CANTERA install, an instruction window containing the following several =
items popped up (this is also in the README.RTF in the Cantera15 directory)=
.  In particular, I tried to do the following:

=3D=3D=3Dbegin=3D=3D=3D

=
=B7	Put the full path to the Python interpreter (e.g. C:\PYTHON23\PYTHON.EX=
E) on the PATH environment variable, or else set environment variable PYTHO=
N_CMD to the path to the interpreter.

=3D=3D=3D=3Dend=3D=3D=3D=3D

So I we=
nt to Windows: System Properties, Advanced, Environment Variables, System V=
ariables and put in the following System Variable:

PYTHON_CMD -> C:\PROGRA=
~1\PYTHON23\

I continued the install, and ran one of the MATLAB demos.  I =
got a number of errors, so I went back in to System Properties, Advanced, E=
nvironment Variables, System Variables and appended the following to my pat=
h:

;C:\PROGRA~1\PYTHON23

and also edited the PYTHON_CMD System Variable a=
s follows:

PYTHON_CMD -> C:\PROGRA~1\PYTHON23\PYTHON.EXE

Only after a reb=
oot did the MATLAB M-file work, but I got several warnings/errors.  I got f=
our (4) in a row of the following messages just before I was told my CPU ti=
me:

=3D=3D=3Dbegin=3D=3D=3D

'C:\PROGRA~1\PYTHON23' is not recognized as a=
n internal or external command, operable program or batch file.

=3D=3D=3D=
=3Dend=3D=3D=3D=3D

I assume that this is not a good thing, and I need to r=
e-compile Python scripts or something to get this error to go away.

1.  Wh=
at do I do, short of an uninstall/re-install

2.  Dave--  you might want to=
 clean up that install message to read:

=3D=3D=3Dbegin=3D=3D=3D

=B7	Inclu=
de the full path to the Python interpreter (e.g. ;C:\PYTHON23) on the PATH =
environment variable, or else set environment variable PYTHON_CMD to the fu=
ll path and file name of the interpreter (e.g. C:\PYTHON23\PYTHON.EXE).

=
=3D=3D=3D=3Dend=3D=3D=3D=3D

TIA,

--Keith

Giner Electrochemical Systems

=
